content.description: This was a fun slab very good feet and hands. Good landing with the pad route goes right up the middle of the slab. It's a head game for sure.

The Crux on this climb is getting out of the start. The holds at the bottom are good yet the angel is steep. Good foot work can set you up to get in the wave and move towards a suspect knob of quartz then top out. It's all rather sharp.
content.location: deep pockets and or mini pinch for right hand start, left hand shallow hueco with small quartz knob for left hand. Good start foot on left face enjoy the difficult balancing start into solid holds and over hanging moves.

content.description: Just below the edge of the boulder face located in the whiter section are two/five pockets (depending if you start facing in or out). Very hard feet to find and difficult to get a good press between the toes. If you can snag the start position it's home free. Enjoy the semi desperate move that leads into the Balancing Act route.
content.location: under the balancing boulder is the start and available pockets. All boulders not part of Balance Boulder are off in order to achieve this grade

content.description: Hydrate V3/4 has some decent crimps to start. Just need to pull hard and move up the obvious cracks. The start and the top make this V3 it's a bit slick at the top otherwise a decent climb.
Stand start on large large hold move up the arete. Hardest part is getting good feet to get started due to the slight over hang.
content.location: Continue Past Balance Boulder about 3 min walk up the burro canyon. You'll see Easter Bunny Boulder.

content.description: Sit start on obvious hueco on the small grounded boulder in the Balance Boulder Area. Make four moves to top out this little guy.
content.location: Large hueco for both hands move straight up and slight right on set of huecos.

content.description: Sit start on the obvious leaning crack the hard part is standing then keeping balance while you move through the very very shallow crack to meet up with Donkey Ears

This shares start holds for Mules Way follow arete up and left through some okay holds to eventually find easier pockets to make the top out. Cold weather makes it feel easier since two holds are utilized by the entire hand and friction makes it feel better.
content.location: Shares Start holds on Mules Way

content.description: This is on the Burro Boulder. This is a stand start and is a great beginner climb it's a fun confidence builder and straight forward climb. unfortunately it's short. Start at the small ledge (two small quarts knobs are also at the small ledge, hence donkey ears) almost half way up the boulder. Move up and left to the obvious leaning edge and top out.
content.location: The last boulder that was established on this trip it's about 15min walk into the canyon. It has more room for development and is worth the short hike.

content.description: This Route is decent and is likely easier than the V4 grade. The top doesn't have the best hands but you are able to transition into the slight slab section to start topping out. this is more of a head game since it goes up the highest part of the boulder and you're slightly over hung moving up the arete.
Start on the left wall at the bottom layer and move up immediately to the fourth layer and then traverse right along the layers of limestone. continue right approximately 50-60 ft.
content.location: Start at the left most edge of the layered limestone. There is a decent sized start at the second layer from the ground to sit start and move up.

content.description: Start on two small shallow pockets just at the over hang. Follow the small set of hands up and right to get into the slight wave section. Go towards the under-cling and then top out.
content.location: Start on two small pockets near the edge of the little over hang.

content.description: There are five bouldering locations in Burro Canyon with one additional boulder that needs development or route establishment. Listed below are the five areas that have established climbs.The following areas can be accessed by continuing to walk into the Burro Canyon. They are listed in order of appearance when walking from the river.The first area "Mini Burro" consists of very easy V0-V1 climbing on large holds. Caution should be used when climbing here since the cracks are deep and may be home to local spiders or scorpions.Mini Burro has a 40ft traverse and multiple V0 and V1 climbs. The vertical routes are approximately 15ft tall and are about 4-6 moves when sit starting.The second area "Balance" is a medium sized boulder that is balanced on two rocks and leaning on a third. This area has one over hanging boulder with four routes on it with more possible routes on the back side. This area has more than four routes but is home to V0-V8. The V8 is still an open project since the feet on the start are difficult to sus out and require some very skilled foot pressing to get off the ground. The V0 is located on the small boulder to the "right" that sits on the ground.The third area "Easter bunny" is a medium sized boulder with more potential but is home to one V3.The fourth area "Droplet Boulder" is home to four routes, a V4 sit start along the arete, a V1 slab along the main slab face, a V3 sit on the left arete/face (difficult sit start but good holds after). Potential for additional climbs on the slab face.The fifth area "Burro" is a small/medium boulder with two routes. One V4 sit start into slab climbing and one V0+ stand start. Potential for more climbs.
